And if you're hungry for more than just potato chip metaphors, check out npr.org.
At our Web site, you can watch a slideshow comparing the three leading candidates to cars, coffee and beer.
I'm Farai Chideya and this is News & Notes.
It is time to put sports on instant replay with our very own Tony Cox.
Hey, Tony.
Hey, Farai.
You know, it's playoff time in baseball.
And if you're just a casual fan, this is when you probably perk up a little bit and start paying attention as we get closer to the World Series in a couple of weeks.
So with me now are two excellent sports minds who have been paying attention all year long, and not just to baseball.
D-Will writes for the blog Sports On My Mind and Greg Lee is online editor for the Boston Globe.
Hey, guys.
Hey, what's going on?
Hey, Tony, how're you doing?
Let's talk a little baseball, shall we.
In most sports, if you have the number record, you are probably going to make it past the first round.
But this year, the two teams with the best records in baseball were knocked out of the playoffs early.
Of course I'm talking about the L.A.
Angels of Anaheim and the Chicago Cubs, the teams with the top records in the American and National Leagues.
Both of them now home watching the playoffs like the rest of us.
D-Will, are these the kinds of surprises that make fans happy, or just drive them crazy?
I think both, Tony, actually.
Chicago people wanted to see Chicago advance.
It is the hundredth year since they last won a World Series, so everyone was excited about that.
At the same time, they were a vastly over-rated club, because the National League is a little bit down this year.
As far as Los Angeles, they have had problems over the last few years beating - defeating the Boston Red Sox in the post-season, so it wasn't that much of a surprise.
However, people are both surprised and they are flummoxed, and all of that.
So yes.
Absolutely.
Well Craig Lee, you know, in the NLCS, which is coming up, we have the L.A.
Dodgers starting a seven-game series today, in fact, against Philadelphia.
Two things for you.
Who do you see coming up on top, because the Dodgers won the division and swept the Cubs in the NLDS, but the last time the Dodgers played in Philly, they were swept.
Well I think it's a different Dodgers team now that Manny Ramirez is there.
He's really hitting the ball real well and his team is feed off of his energy.
And I think that the Dodgers will beat the Phillies for the simple fact that Manny Ramirez has been there, done that with his two World Series rings that he brought along from Boston.
And I really think he's going to - he's really, really motivated to get the World Series and hopefully face his old team.
Well you know what?
D-Will, on Friday, the Tampa Bay Rays square off against the Boston Red Sox in the American League.
They meet at Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg.
These teams really don't like each other, do they?
I mean, I remember their big bench-clearing brawl back in June.
Right, yes.
Tampa Bay has grown in stature and maturity, and actually they don't like the Yankees, they don't like Boston, they don't like any of the AL East teams they play against.
And this is going to be very interesting.
I think Tampa might actually beat Boston, even though I personally see Boston and L.A.
playing in the World Series.
I think Tampa might do it, because they have a never-say-die attitude and they - I think they have as many clutch hitters as the Red Sox do.
And they have good pitching as well.
Absolutely.
But to D-Will's point, Greg, seems like a lot of folks want to see L.A.
and the Red Sox.
Of course, Manny is one reason for that.
But is that the only reason?
There are several reasons.
Around here, we call L.A.
Dodgers Boston West.
I mean, there are a lot of story lines there.
You've got Frank McCourt, the Boston real estate mogul who owns the Dodgers.
There are a lot of Dodgers who used to play for the Red Sox, including Derek Lowe...
Garciaparra.
Nomar Garciaparra.
That's right.
So there's a lot of connections there.
And remember, the manager is Joe Torre, who has had a lot of battles with the Red Sox.
So there are so many different story lines outside of the obvious with Manny Ramirez being traded in mid-season this year.
All right.
We'll have to follow and see how that goes.
Let's move on to college football, gentlemen.
We've got a couple of big college football games this week.
Number-one-ranked Oklahoma taking on fifth-ranked Texas in a Big 12 match-up, defending national champion and fourth-ranked LSU goes to the Swamp at number-11 Florida in a SEC match-up.
Give me your thoughts about that first, D-Will.
Let's - these are two excellent match-ups.
I'm down here in Austin, so you can imagine, everything's at a fever pitch down here.
I think Oklahoma actually is the better team this year.
They are amazing on both sides of the ball.
As far as the battle in the swamp is concerned, it's going to be a defensive struggle that I think LSU might just win.
Really?
What do you think, Boston?
Well obviously, in Texas and Oklahoma you both - both teams have two great quarterbacks in Colt McCoy in Texas and Sam Bradford in Oklahoma.
But I really think that Oklahoma - yes, as D-Will has mentioned - have it on both sides of the ball.
Their defense is very dominating and suffocating, and I think the Sooners will take care of Texas.
As far as LSU and Florida, being Louisiana-bred that I am, I really think that LSU's defense really will go down into the Swamp and beat Florida.
I think Florida, you know, showed a little weakness when they lost to Old Miss.
Maybe a lack of focus, but losing to Old Miss was not a good thing for Florida.

And I really think LSU is really finding themselves and finding their groove, especially with their young quarterback Jarrett Lee, who really stepped up big time a couple weeks ago in Auburn and led LSU to a victory at Auburn.
The leadership of both parties, the majority in the House and the majority in the Senate, went behind closed doors and made that provision just magically disappear.
Grassley says this is a victory for Wall Street interests.
Well, the thing I remember most about it was the smell.
Greg Lee, I'm going to have to stop calling you Boston and start calling you Baton Rouge, I suppose.
I think one of the interesting side stories guys, this season is that some of the smaller schools are doing really well.
Talking now about Bringham Young, Boise State, they're in the top 20.
And also tiny Ball State has even cracked AP's top 25.
Aren't these schools, D-Will, supposed to have inferior programs, at least compared to the big Division 1A schools?
Well yes, they do as far as depth is concerned.
But these starters on both sides of the ball for these smaller schools are equal now in talent to the larger schools.
And as long as they can avoid injuries or get into a smash-mouth type of game the way that college offensive systems are, they can spread the field, run the ball.
As long as you have a good set of core athletes, these smaller schools can keep up.
And with the multitude of athletes across the country and the fewer scholarships that are allowed in college football, it allows these athletes to go to smaller schools.
So I think this is great and I think it's going to continue.
That was my question to you, Greg.
How are these schools getting these athletes?
And D-Will just partly explained it.
Yes.
Yes, everyone is now limited to 85 scholarships.
So the scholarships are spread out more across the country.
And you have to realize too, college football is on TV everywhere.
So everyone is getting a piece of that national exposure that every high school senior is looking for when they go to college.
Just because they can't get into Michigan, and Michigan is always on TV, they can get into the Ball States, because Ball State is shown on TV.
Brigham Young is shown on the Mountain Network and Mountain West.
So it's shown nationally on DirectTV and that sort.

And so with the number of scholarships and plus TV exposure being increased even more so for all these schools to be exposed, a lot of kids are going to different types of schools outside from the Michigans and the Floridas.
Let me come to you, D-Will.
I've got another college football question, because we have seen a lot of upsets at the college level so far this season.
And a lot of these upsets seem to be coming during weekday games, like on Thursday.
Yes.
Like USC versus Oregon.
Just one example as couple of weeks ago.
This is, of course, a television phenomenon putting the games on on Thursday.
And I know that programs do get a certain amount of exposure from those weekday games.
But it seems to me - and I'd like your opinion - that playing midweek can not be helpful to the student athlete?
No, it isn't.
And particularly for the bigger schools.
They don't need the exposure.
They don't need to build a reputation.
For these smaller schools like Oregon State - and it is a large school, but it's smaller in stature than USC is as far as its football program is concerned.
That game was a Super Bowl type of game or national championship game for Oregon State.
It is their one chance to play on national television and show the country what they're about.
In the case of Oregon State, they came off a bye week, they had nine full days to prepare for that game.
And this was everything to them.
And this was everything to them.
And that's how these upsets occur.
Additionally, for the larger schools and the athletes in those schools, the athletes who are going to be professionals, those games often can only hurt their status in the NFL - coming NFL draft.

A bad game on national television during the middle of the week when it's the only game on television can drop their draft stock from a first round draft choice to a third round draft choice because those - the sport jocks and the ESPNs of the world will never let them - never let you forget that they had that bad game under quote, pressure.
You know, you're absolutely right.
You're absolutely right.
Let's talk, though, about the guys that play on Sunday now instead of the guys who just play on Saturday and Thursday and whenever the heck they play.
